PART.TITLE: Preparing for Auto-Installation
PART.PARTINTRO:
Getting Started
Depending on the installation environment, hardware settings and the complexity of the configuration certain preparations have to take place before any installation can take place.
Examine if auto-installation is actually a solution for you
Installing a single client in an interactive way using &company-suse; is only a couple of clicks away. So if you intention is to install only a small number of systems which differ in hardware and configuration maybe it is faster to install them the traditional way.
Auto-Installation gets to be interesting when installing large number of machines which at least have one thing in common. For example auto-installation can be used for installing a network of workstation which share the same environemnt and have similar hardware.
Collect information
You need to collect information about the machines to be installed. This includes hardware and network information. Please make sure you know the following about the machines you want to install:
Hard disk types and sizes
Graphic interface and attached monitor if any
Network insterface and MAC address if know
With these parameters you are ready to go and create a control file to control the auto-installation process.
Create the control file
To create a control file you either can use the configuration system which covers most of the features of the auto-installation system or you can use your favourite editor. In some cases you may need to add some information manually after creating the control file with the configuration system
After creating the control file, make sure it has a valid syntax. The easy way to check the syntax is by using some tools already available on the distribution. For example to verfiy that the file is well formed, use the utility tidy from the package with the same name.
tidy -xml <control file>
If the control file is not well formed, i.e. if a tag is not closed, tidy will have an output similar to the following:
line 11 column 3 - Warning: unexpected </pre-scripts> in <script> line 12 column 2 - Warning: unexpected </configure> in <script> line 13 column 1 - Warning: unexpected </profile> in <script> This document has errors that must be fixed before using HTML Tidy to generate a tidied up version.
Before going on with the auto-installation, please fix any errors resulting from such checks. The auto-installation process can't be started with non-well formed control files.
Decide how you wish to boot the target system.
A target system can be booted in different ways. Booting the machine and initiating the auto-installation process is as important as the installation itself. Depending on how many target systems you wish to install, the following methods are supported:
Floppy
Not recommended in complex network environments. A Floppy nowadays can't hold all necessary information needed to setup a machine for installation. A Floppy should only be used in very special cases and if it is used, the default boot floppy compenents supplied with &company-suse; must be modifed to match you exact needs.
However, the floppy can be used to store the control file and other information needed for installation.
CD-ROM
You can use the original &company-suse; CD-ROMs in compenation with other media, i.e. with a floppy to hold the control file or in compenation with network where the control file can be located.
It is also possible to create customized CD-ROMs to hold only the package you need in addition to the control file which also can be saved on the CD-ROM. This method requires creation of CD-ROMs everytime you wish to change the configuration though.
Network
Using the network to boot a target system is the most convinient way for auto-installing. Booting over the network and holding a repository of control files on an accessible server can be very flexible especially when configuring different types of system with different roles and hardware.
